title: Why the Fuck isn't there a Zac or Maokai Feedback thread
body: So the PBE can abuse Riot for poor changes and compliment good ones, and point out GLARING ISSUES

replies.body:
My best bet is that Riot didn't plan to make any threads for any of the three champs and made the Sejuani thread only as a snap response to the overwhelming amount of criticism they were receiving.

Still I agree with you, there should have been a thread released for each one of them on the day they were released on the PBE.
I don't think anyone was expecting this much backlash. They murdered poor Maokai's identity and want to ship a Nami 2.0 in tank form. I was pretty okay with Zac but Sejuani just feels wonky.
Yeah I'm not a fan of the Maokai changes. They don't even fix the problem of him being a generalist, which is what they stated they intended to fix.

Riot doesn't know how to achieve the goals of their rework unless they completely rebuild the champion from the ground up. Even in that case, they fail more often than not -- take a look at Ryze and Eveylnn for examples of this specific issue.

More than that, they aren't acting like they have any goals in mind.  Oh you want him to be a jungler again, so you reduce his W speed (I know the one we saw was a bug, but it's still planned on being slowed) and you _don't_ revert to the longer range before the first rework?  Like, are you only testing these changes in Plastic 7 games where no one wards or realizes they have a minimap?  Because unless he blows ult on cooldown while he's gankning, he has virtually no chance of succeeding vs semi-functioning humans.

Zac needs to bounce more.

My Ideal ZAC ult that stays with the current design route is as follows:

Zac bounces X times, X=amount of champions he has absorbed and deposits one champion after each bounce.
The bouncing and goofyness is what made it so much more than just another "malphite ultimate"
THIS, I HAD THE SAME IDEA

How is Zac's new ult anything like Malphite's? If you charge it you basically get an Azir-tier ultimate where the enemy is completely displaced from where they want to be. It might come off like Malphite's ulti if you use it instantly, but that's not the only thing it can do.

I'm all for bouncing but being stretchy also feels "Zac." If Zac's W was redone to make him bounce instead of just a vanilla explosion, I would prefer that instead.
Generic Knock up

Why? Because riot continues to arrogantly think they're always right. 
See previous failed reworks.

Skarner was and forever will be Failure, Why? The GImmick where he is only powerful in those Zones. That power could have been spread throughout his Kit making him a much better champion, and allowing him more diversity in builds and roles.

Skarner is already on the list for another rework, but he's still a great champion right now. I could say the same about Shen, Graves, Fiora, and Garen. 

I can't say I enjoy playing against any of those champions, but who cares? Their reworks did what they were supposed to, except maybe Skarner.

I dare you to play Shen and Skarner Top lane. at least 5 five times each. I could almost guarantee you'll lose 70%.

and while SKarner is viable, he feels terrible to play due to his gimmick (literally the only problem ), compare to how he was before.

I doubt I would lose on Shen top that often, he's a strong champion in general. 

Playing Skarner top makes no sense though. Why play a Jungler top to prove your point? Tell me to play him in the jungle then, which I have done, and he feels great still.

That's because they hired Ghostcrawler who ruined WoW PvP (trust me, I was there during his reign).

I mean i was too, but WoW had far more issues than just PvP getting ruined. 
It was the pigeonholing mentality which said that "we want you to be unable to 'make mistakes' and in order to do that we will remove player agency to increase game consistency".

It's a bad philosophy which goes directly contrary to the concept of what makes something a game.

I guess you could call it an authoritarian philosophy of game design, but i hesitate to use a political term in an online discussion.

I'ma defend GC here because I feel like that's not a position he shared. That particular quote was from J. Allen Brack, who is a detached moron with a swollen head and  sense of importance. For Ghost on the other hand, I still have heavy concerns about him considering his influence during his time at Blizzard, and coincidentally, even though he disagreed with the developer policy of "don't talk to the community," Riot started practicing this immediately after he joined.  The biggest problem I have with him as a League dev is his response to feedback, where he picks out certain topics, and spends a considerable amount of effort, going on for 6 paragraphs, only to say nothing at all - like a politician. 

 Politicians can spend 15 minutes on a speech to rally support, but when you really listen to them, you'll notice that sometimes...they didn't say much of anything (or they'll be misleading or just straight up wrong,) but their supporters will  defend them because they liked what they heard, even if they don't fully understand.
They've had it for a few years now. It's not exactly a new position they've taken, it's just that it took a while for people to see it.
I'd love to have a dedicated place to share my thoughts on my fave, but Riot's gonna ship all of them as-is anyway because they don't really _care_ about the feedback they get.

Same reason why they sometimes randomly buff champions out of nowhere, just so that people will pick them up again, until the point where they do this too many times, continuously giving champs needless tiny buffs that eventually break the champion and makes it OP when it finally receives a major, needed buff.
